Commissioner, you are no doubt aware that the most intense discussions we have had here regarding your communication concern the place of public services and services of general interest in the single market and their legislative implementation.
We have reached a compromise formulation that invites you to go beyond your proposal twenty-five and we ask you to go beyond a simple one.
communication that does not meet the expectations and needs of the actors, users, and all stakeholders of public services, and that does not meet the objectives that you otherwise set.
The European Union must convey a clear and unambiguous message on public services.
To do this, we need to create a positive legal framework, regulation or directive.
The Lisbon Treaty provides us with the legal basis for this.
it is up to you to translate them into legislative proposals now.
I believe that Parliament is ready to follow you down this path.
Mr President, first of all, congratulations to all the rapporteurs for their enormous work on this discharge, and I also welcome the Council's presence for this debate.
The seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg is a matter of European identity and is not just a matter of economics.

I am speaking about this today in this chamber on the occasion of the debate on the discharge for the year 2009, because the symbol of Franco-German reconciliation is being treated by some members of the Committee on Budgetary Control as a mere means of making savings.
I am also interested in the issue of Parliament's expenditure.
In this regard, I propose that we hold the group weeks in Strasbourg rather than in Brussels, which would allow us to make better use of our Parliament headquarters in Strasbourg.
Since we want to save money, I propose other measures, such as eliminating the Friday per diem for our colleagues, as well as eliminating per diems for journalists.
Europe is attractive enough that one is not obliged to give a tenth to journalists.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument to appropriate an important issue that goes beyond budgetary control, even though I commend the important work of Villeux, our rapporteur, on this discharge.
Finally, since we are talking about the economy, I also want to see a moralization and a cleaning up of the compensation system for groups of sponsored visitors.

I don't find it very moral, and it gives a very bad image of our institution, that the group leader is reimbursed in cash, on the day of the visit, without any work, without any control of what the group has spent.
Sometimes, as I would like to point out, the allocated sum exceeds the amount of actual expenses.

It would be logical for groups to send a quote in advance to the visits department, receive an account from Parliament for expenses, and this to a bank account, and for the balance to be paid upon presentation of the invoices that have actually been paid, with a ceiling obviously. Thank you.
Madam President, I am addressing the Commission, my colleagues, and I welcome the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today stems from the management of the Schengen area in 2011.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s; on the contrary, it is a space that has continuously expanded in recent years and now includes twenty-five states, three of which are not members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, Schengen cooperation must therefore adapt to the reality it now covers, which is no longer the same as it was ten years ago.

This is the context in which the proposals of the Italian and French governments and the pragmatic and necessary responses provided today by the Commission in its communication on immigration should be read.
Mutual trust between the Schengen states is indeed the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on mutual obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air leaks, the entire system becomes faulty.
It should therefore be possible for other states to respond to this failure by re-establishing temporary and strictly controlled surveillance of these borders.
In doing so, these failing states will be clearly invited to better control their external borders.

Moreover, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the spirit of Schengen, insofar as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be made at the European level and not at the intergovernmental level.
Such measures will be intrinsically linked to all measures envisaged in the long term with a view to a common migration policy.
It is particularly essential to strengthen Frontex and to provide more solidarity to support the states located at the external borders.
The situation in the Mediterranean in recent years has only highlighted a shortcoming in the Schengen acquis.
In a few weeks, migrants from the countries bordering the Mediterranean have accounted for a significant percentage of annual French immigration.
This achievement is not static, but must, on the contrary, evolve.
I hope that these proposals will be adopted quickly, ensuring better management of our Schengen area and, in doing so, ensuring the security of our common external borders. Thank you.
Mr President, the European Union has finally imposed sanctions on Syria.
But unfortunately, she seems to be doing so with a trembling hand, carefully avoiding any criticism of the head of the Syrian regime.
This lack of determination and clarity is obviously interpreted by the protesters as a form of abandonment and by the government as an indulgence that allows it to intensify the
repression, such cruel repression that one cannot even imagine for a moment that at the same time, Syria could be elected to sit on the Human Rights Council of the organization
of the United Nations, while today the Syrian authorities are denying UN observers access to the city of Dera, the scene of terrible violence against defenseless civilians.

Syria on the Human Rights Council would be an insult to the victims and their families, an encouragement for this regime to use brutal force against its people, in contempt, rightly so, of the values that the Human Rights Council is supposed to uphold.
So, Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options are you considering to avoid such a disaster?

Madam Mathieu, Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Carlos Coelho, who has done a jeweler's job on this report, and God knows it was very complicated.
Bulgaria and Romania have made considerable efforts to strengthen control of their borders and have succeeded.
Whether it's police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy, or the control of air, sea or land borders, the latest assessments are very clear.
all technical criteria are met.
We can only acknowledge this state of affairs.
Bulgaria and Romania are now in a position to implement this Schengen acquis in terms of both technology and personnel.
Moreover, while there are currently no obstacles preventing the enlargement of the Schengen area, we note that a number of recommendations have been addressed to these two countries.

I hope that these recommendations will be strictly monitored, particularly with regard to the borders between Bulgaria, Greece and Turkey, because, as you know, mutual trust between Schengen States is based on the full compliance by these States with their reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties fails to meet its obligations and creates air leaks, the entire system becomes faulty.
I sincerely hope that an agreement will be reached in the Council to welcome these two countries into the privileged circle of Schengen states.
and we will all measure in this chamber the impact of this type of decision on the citizens concerned.
Once again, congratulations to Mr. Coelho for his report. Thank you, Mr. President.
Mr President, in its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself the objective of making our economy greener and our transport more modern.
All European institutions have broadly supported this objective, including almost all the Member States and our Parliament.
In this context, it is therefore regrettable that, since 2008, several Member States have worked to strip the new Eurovignette Directive proposal of its content and block this issue.

Today, however, thanks to the perseverance of our rapporteur - and I would like to pay tribute here to Sad el Khadraoui - and thanks to the perseverance of the shadow rapporteurs in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

Certainly, this text is much less ambitious than the initial proposal, but it will allow for the first time to put into practice the polluter pays principle and to internalize external transport costs such as noise or CO2 emissions.

In order for this Eurovignette to be more than just a tax, but to actually contribute to improving transport in Europe, Member States are also encouraged to reinvest the money collected in modernizing transport modes.
Parliament has also managed to secure concrete developments in the interoperability of toll systems, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy goods vehicles.

In order to remain consistent with the political objectives set by our institution, I sincerely hope that we will be able to adopt the compromise proposed to us in second reading and thus pave the way for a more sustainable transport policy. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, I agree that, along with liberty and fraternity, there should be equality with the peasants and the countries that have rejoined the Eastern countries that have rejoined.
Yes, I agree with you.
I believe we have taken a major step forward with this report.
It wasn't easy at first and we were more in a confrontation, but we reached a consensus and that's what's most important.
This consensus helps to protect the overall project, and I believe that this is the great merit of the European Parliament.
We succeeded in this endeavor, and it was not easy. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteur Murciudes and all the parliamentarians.
First step.
In this text, we reaffirm the need for both equality, justice and fairness between producers and between territories, and I believe this is important.
We have said very clearly and confirmed the maintenance and development of small farms, the consideration of small farms, which is essential for the quality and biodiversity of the territories.
I believe that was also fundamental.
The introduction of the concept of making agriculture agronomic, and turning the page on industrial, productivist agriculture, has been enshrined in the texts.
Now we need to implement this. It is a condition for making agriculture possible for future generations.
This is not an ideological issue.
Finally, today, our concern is that there are indeed threats to the budget.
This must be answered clearly.

Now, what we are waiting for is to enter the second phase, which is clearly the legislative debate, because beyond the texts and the grand intentions, it is in the legislative debate that we will truly see where we are going, and that is what we are waiting for, of course, now.
I would like to finish by letting out a cry of anger against Germany's attitude, which has led to a fivefold reduction in food aid to the poorest in Europe.
It was within the CAP budget.
I want us to find a way to help the poorest people. There are eighty million European citizens who do not eat properly.
Mr President, while the European Parliament can boast of some significant advances in economic governance, I urge my colleagues to show humility, because we are dancing on the edge of the abyss.
Let us be well aware of two things.
The first is that the European Parliament remained inaudible during the Greek crisis.
While we are usually so quick to react to all kinds of events with resolutions all over the world, this existential crisis seems to leave us speechless.
I deeply regret that we were unable to send a strong, concrete, and simple message to the Greeks, the governments of the member states, and European citizens.
The second observation concerns the scope of this package.
By voting for what I hope will be these six directives and the regulation, we will certainly take the euro area a step forward.
more towards a discipline that we have missed so much, a step, I say, nothing more that will show its usefulness in the future.
But one need only look at the heated discussions surrounding the reversed qualified majority to measure the distance we still have to travel, when it should be about rules and automatic sanctions.
The mechanism of reversed qualified majority continues to act as a bogeyman for some.
We must, however, remain firm on the principle.
On a strictly political level, I regret that the left benches continue to reject the principles of sound budgetary management against all evidence.
Yes, deficit and sustainable growth are antonyms.

Yes, states must also manage their budget like a good family man, but not by stimulating the economy through public spending. This is a sweet poison in the short term, but it is never a sustainable solution.
As the coming weeks prove crucial, today it is a matter of re-establishing an economic union.
This morning, after three years of work, we voted on a text that is very important for the progress of consumer protection in Europe.
It rightly focuses on online shopping, which may account for 25% of all commerce in Europe in twenty years, which is quite considerable.
These purchases will notably be cross-border.
They will allow consumers to have a wider choice and also to pay much less.
This is real progress.
For SMEs, for all craftsmen, it is also a very important opportunity to expand their market outlets.

Among the main advances, I would like to mention just two: the withdrawal period is extended to fourteen days, and all the information and the total price to be paid are recapitulated before the final step of placing the order.

Finally, I am proud, in the context of these explanations of vote, to say that I, but all our colleagues, voted unanimously across the political groups, because on such a subject, it was not polemics that we needed, but obviously consensus.
If we have obtained it.

Mathieu, two minutes. Welcome, Commissioner. Madam President, Commissioners, I would first like to commend the efforts of our colleague Carlos Coelho on this very difficult issue that required a great deal of technical expertise, hard work, and knowledge of the subject matter.
The control of our common territory and our European borders is one of the most important challenges we face, and technology is more than ever at the service of this challenge.
In fact, over the past few years, we have witnessed an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some call a digital tsunami is certain to become a reality in the coming years.
The SIS, VIS, and Eurodac are all essential instruments today for ensuring the security of our European citizens.
Ensuring good operational management of these databases is therefore a major issue to which it is our responsibility to provide an effective response.

This response is of course very delicate and Carlos Coelho had to face numerous legal, institutional, budgetary, political and technical obstacles, and he has nevertheless managed to produce a balanced text that satisfies all the parties concerned.
The creation of this agency for networks appears to be the best solution for ensuring the internal security of the member states.
No other existing institution or agency could take charge of the proper management of these information systems today.

It will improve the management of existing information systems, it will offer better synergy between these databases and will also allow for the integration of instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the most delicate issues that arose in this matter was the location of the Agency's headquarters: where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have put themselves forward as candidates to host it.

France already hosts the Schengen Information System in Strasbourg, where it has been managing its operational and administrative aspects since 1995, and as a result, it has full technical control over it.
Following the conclusions of the European Council in December 2003, which gave priority to the new Member States, Estonia also wanted to host the seat of this future agency.

I believe that the compromise reached is very good. A kind of distribution of tasks has taken place, I conclude, Madam President, by transferring the Agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where governance, strategy, and program design tasks will be carried out.
The development and operation of the systems will take place in Strasbourg
The cost-effectiveness ratio is well balanced and this compromise solution does not undermine the centralized management of IT systems.
Mr President, the horizontal social clause and Article 14 of the Lisbon Treaty provide binding guarantees for social rights, including the right of access to services of general interest.
It is time to prove to European citizens that social Europe is on the move.

Our social achievements must therefore be given the place they deserve in Community law, by recognising the specific nature of SGEIs in relation to competition rules, bearing in mind that these services have strong local roots and rely on social economy players.

Mr. de Rosa's report is an opportunity to reaffirm the simple yet powerful principles of equality and universal access to these collectively organized services, which are essential for social well-being and progress.
Commissioner, you said it is time to move on to the practicalities.
Yes, it is time to move on to the practical aspects. In this debate, I propose that we actually create a European legislative instrument for social services.
I therefore invite you to vote for the alternative resolution tabled by the Greens.
Mr. President, debates on GMOs must necessarily be based on irrefutable arguments, both scientifically and legally.
Legally, a wide range of solid arguments were needed for Member States wishing to restrict or ban GMOs on their territory.
The rapporteur has expanded the range of options available.
I, for one.
As for the scientific basis, it must be irrefutable, too.
The Council has repeatedly challenged EFSA's scientific assessments, which have always been positive towards GMOs, in contrast to national scientific assessments.

To restore confidence, would it not be necessary, first and foremost, Commissioner, to simply apply the existing legislation that aims to provide a great deal of scientific guarantees, particularly in terms of long-term impact assessment?
Why have the Council's recommendations from October two thousand eight remained unimplemented?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner. First of all, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Bouzitil for the tremendous work he has accomplished.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal and we can only congratulate her for that.
This report outlines for us an agency with increased resources, more in line with the missions assigned to it.
Recent events have demonstrated the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, the Member States, and the support of a strong agency.
Frontex finally gets the means to fulfill its missions.
By being able to acquire or rent its own equipment and benefit from the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and very effective.
New tasks are also assigned to them, such as organizing voluntary returns or processing personal data, so that we can combat cross-border crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of Frontex's scope of competence enables us to consider and address migration issues through a comprehensive approach, rather than confining ourselves to a mere mechanical border management.
I approve the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, including Europol.
Finally, the human dimension has taken its rightful place in this report.
A strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to establish an advisory board within the Agency.

I can only welcome this comprehensive proposal that takes a step forward towards sound and responsible management of our external borders in a context where migratory pressures are particularly strong and continue to grow. Thank you.

Mr President, I should like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Meyer, and my fellow Members for their comments, which have sometimes been critical, but this 2010 activity report is finally a great opportunity to talk about the Committee on Petitions, as it remains too little known.
Yet it is the Commission that has a direct, sometimes physical, link with the citizen, who can attend our debates in person.
She has undeniable legitimacy in Parliament, as well as extensive expertise due to her direct relationship with citizens.
In fact, any petitioner can go to Parliament and defend their rights before the petitions committee.
One can also appreciate the serenity of the debates, despite the painful cases that are often addressed.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be: listening to the problems of its citizens and united in finding solutions and protecting them.
Unfortunately, the means of action and the means of exerting influence remain limited, particularly with regard to the environmental risks of projects that are sometimes almost complete.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases, such as family rights or children's rights in the event of a divorce.
We will also be conducting a mission on this topic in November.
I also regret that national authorities do not always rush to provide us with all the necessary information.
I would like to thank the European Commission for the research and verification work it carries out, even if sometimes it could go further in the search for truth.
I must also acknowledge the constructive work we are doing with the European Ombudsman.
Finally, I appeal to citizens to continue to contact us, through petitions, as directly elected representatives.
Our role will always be to safeguard your interests in strict compliance with European law.
Madam President, Commissioner, I welcome this resolution on homelessness because it is our responsibility to remind everyone of its extreme urgency.
First, we note that what was a priority yesterday remains even more pressing today.

The lack of reliable definitions and statistical indicators on homelessness cannot prevent us from noting, as the crisis worsens, that the number of people living below the poverty line has increased, according to Eurostat, from 79 million in 2009 to an estimated 84 million in 2011.
Dear colleagues, three years ago, our Parliament, concerned about eradicating poverty, asked the Member States to put an end to the problem of STF by the year 2015.
Today, we have ourselves come somewhat closer to our goal.
Has the year 2010, dedicated to the fight against poverty, really been put to good use by the member states to concretely address this major precariousness, the urgency of which has become permanent?
I genuinely doubt it and I deeply regret it.

In conclusion, I would like to emphasize the need to develop a comprehensive, multisectoral strategy to address homelessness, because, of course, there is poverty and lack of housing, but there are also family problems, health issues, various addictions, and personal vulnerability.
A comprehensive, effective, ambitious, but tailored approach is needed, one that takes into account individuals, the heterogeneous nature of their experiences, and the disruptions in their lives.
It is a right, at the very least a fundamental one, from which many of the most vulnerable are deprived.
Madam President, as everyone has said, in recent years the European Union has been hit by unprecedented disasters, and listing them all would take up the entire debate.
I will, however, mention the Azedef explosion, the tenth anniversary of which we commemorated less than a week ago in Toulouse.
A reinforced reaction at the European level, as proposed in Mrs. Gardini's report, represents a real opportunity to demonstrate solidarity among our populations.

For several years now, the Union has been trying to make this pooling of our efforts operational, and it is now time to act together and not wait for another catastrophe to strike our territories before we learn from it.
Today, it is a matter of making our material, human, and financial resources available to everyone in order to prevent new tragedies from occurring.
Commissioner, earlier you said that we need to anticipate risks.

And it is truly regrettable that, in this context, the European Commission is considering withdrawing funding from the GMES satellite observation program, which is recognized by all as an essential instrument for preventing and coordinating disaster responses.
I urge the Commission to reconsider this position and to support these flagship programs that provide Europe with undeniable added value.
I would like to thank Mrs Gardini for her excellent report.
I hope we will adopt it, as it will pave the way for European solidarity in the service of the citizen. Thank you.
Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, the number of poor and unemployed people continues to rise within the European Union.
More than forty-three million Europeans are threatened by food poverty.
The situation is serious.
Today, six member states want to end the food aid program without any replacement: Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and the Czech Republic.
Certainly, there is a decision from the Court of Justice and we must respect it.
However, Commissioner, Parliament questioned you last July, at the initiative of our Green group, and you made relevant proposals to safeguard the programme.
The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions, but when millions of people depend on this system, we cannot allow the food aid budget to be cut by four.
The emergency is real.

If nothing is done by the end of the year, the food bank will be missing more than three hundred million euros, and there is no guarantee that national governments will be able to take over to fill this gap.
It is therefore a real question of solidarity between peoples.
Let us not allow an irresponsible governing minority to deprive millions of Europeans of food aid, because this is first and foremost a matter of survival.
The fight against poverty and malnutrition also requires a reform of the CAP.
We need to fundamentally change the way we produce food in order to bring food production closer to people, especially the poorest who are entitled to a healthy and balanced diet.
Only a truly sustainable CAP will enable us to ensure that fewer Europeans will need food aid.
The Council must come to its senses and allow those in need to access this vital aid.
I am particularly addressing the future Danish government, which will be responsible for ensuring the presidency of the European Union starting in January.
Come to your senses. Does it take food riots in Europe to realize the urgent need to change our logic?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council has found solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, there is no one left. The Parliament has sent a strong message the last time: Human beings are more important than finance.
finances, it is high time to reaffirm it
In any case, we will be very vigilant and we will not fail to renew our appeal in a constructive manner.
Six Member States hold in their hands the fate of eighteen million Europeans in need.
six Member States which claim to be doing no more and no less than legalism.
Legalism is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we not express our anger towards those who remain deaf to the alarm calls made by associations that help the most deprived?

And do we, as Members of the European Parliament, representatives of all citizens, want a Europe where national selfishness dictates policies, paying little heed to the citizens of countries in budgetary difficulty?
There is no question of renationalizing this aid.

No, let's maintain this program, give it a stronger legal basis, but let's not abandon those who, in the immediate term, in two thousand twelve, are counting on this aid in particularly difficult times of crisis. Thank you.

Mr President, Commissioner, I will not dwell on the cynicism with which the ArcelorMittal group announced the closure of some of its facilities in Europe, and in particular in Belgium, in Lige, ultimately leading to hundreds of direct job losses and putting several thousand indirect jobs at risk.
As a native of Lige, I share the astonishment and dismay of the five hundred and eighty-one workers who have been laid off from their family.
But I am also thinking of the severe restructuring announced by the steel group in France, Germany and Luxembourg.
The reasons cited are always the same: poor prospects for the steel market in Europe, fierce competition from imports from China, Korea,
Russia and Brazil, the reduction in the automotive market, and finally the competitiveness gap, for example of the Lige site, compared to the best factories in Northern Europe.
In addition, despite a difficult year in 2010, the financial center of the steel group ArcelorMittal Belgium generated a profit of one billion three hundred eighty-four million euros.
He paid zero euros in taxes, resulting in a tax rate of zero.
This is particularly shocking.
The group's management is primarily financial, with a stop-and-go policy implemented across several sites.
And in the minds of these leaders, the closure of sites is nothing more than an economic adjustment variable where human issues are of little importance.
it is no longer acceptable. So,
You spoke, Commissioner, about the rules.
Is it not time for the Commission to develop a binding code of social responsibility for multinational corporations?

It has been six years since our Parliament adopted a report on relocation, the code of conduct for companies, the reimbursement of subsidies, and mandatory consultation between companies, trade unions, and public authorities.
Since then, it must be acknowledged that little concrete progress has been made on these various proposals.
So, what does the Commission intend to do about this and within what timeframe?
If we want to support the competitiveness of companies and make Europe attractive in terms of economic investment, we also need to adopt a legislative framework.
Europe needs to be strong to cope with relocation and restructuring, and to ensure that another form of capital, human capital, is fully taken into account.
Finally, in the case of the Lige site, I hope it will be able to benefit from the intervention of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the dismissed workers. Thank you.

Madam President, my dear colleagues, the wave of layoffs that is affecting workers across Europe must lead us to reflect on the role that we, as political leaders, have to play in the face of multinational companies that act...

without any social ethics, which carry out stock market layoffs and relocate to reduce costs, increase shareholder profits, and please rating agencies, disregarding social and environmental standards.

In its resolution of September 20th on the future of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, Parliament clearly expressed its desire to support, above all, the employees affected by the negative consequences of restructuring.

But we also asked the Commission to ensure consistency between the interventions of the European Fisheries Fund and the industrial policy of the European Union, particularly through the use of structural funds.

We also insisted that the future EGF regulation include improvements so that the Fund does not produce the random, moral effects it currently has on multinational companies, as is the case with ArcelorMittal and Nokia.
Commissioner, we can no longer continue to look separately at the issue of structural funds and the Globalisation Adjustment Fund without
considering the restructuring strategies of companies that benefit from them without examining the cost-benefit ratio of a policy, I repeat, is indeed...
Mr President, the European Ombudsman conducts investigations into complaints against the institutions and bodies of the European Union with great success.

This instrument is both necessary to facilitate the free movement of our businesses and citizens, but it is also a formidable guarantee, especially in the face of the Union's detractors who all too often say that the European Union is nothing more than a bureaucratic machine without control.
This is clearly nonsensical. Europe is genuinely working on itself, thanks to the European Ombudsman, among others.
But let me relay a finding that I deeply regret, in which the Commission is under fire for criticism.
First of all, the correct number of investigations opened by the Ombudsman concerning the European Commission is sixty-five, not twelve.

There are also stakeholders. Many companies come to us to express their frustration with a European Commission that remains unresponsive to their requests, particularly regarding access to documents. Similarly, regarding the issue of transparency in decision-making,
Few people understand it.
Finally, from personal experience, I must admit that I have sometimes been shocked by the reactions of certain European Commission services present in the Committee on Petitions.
As you know, the European Commission provides us with its position on petitions, a position that we always take into account and which is necessary.

But it occasionally happens to see representatives of the European Commission who refuse to answer a Member's questions or who hide behind empty words almost as well as politicians, and this in front of citizens pleading their cause.

I therefore wanted to remind you that Europe must have a human face, that behind the administrative problems identified and resolved by the Ombudsman are Europeans, relieved to be heard but disappointed by his work.
Citizens' behaviors are then negatively marked by their confrontation with the institutions, potentially creating a sense of revolt, incomprehension, and, in the long term, perhaps Euroscepticism.
I sincerely hope that these criticisms and those of the Ombudsman against the institutions in general are heard. Thank you.
Madam President, professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and competitiveness of our European Union, these are indeed the terms in which today's topic is framed.
We, the EPP Group, have supported the report by our colleague Mrs McClarkin, a report in the drafting of which we have played a significant role and which we obviously support.

The main recommendations of this report are for greater professional mobility, greater simplification and efficiency in the procedures for recognizing professional qualifications, while ensuring patient safety and consumer safety.
But it is in terms of the path to growth that the challenge of increasing professional mobility arises.
Moreover, the Forum for a Single Market held in Krakow at the beginning of October did not make a mistake about this.

who pointed out that the Member States had to recognise the potential of the internal market for boosting growth and job creation and had to act to remove all obstacles to the completion of the internal market.
Similarly, the European Council of October 23rd also set as one of the essential priorities for achieving growth, in my words, intelligent, sustainable,
including the implementation of the twelve priority proposals in the Single Market Act, the twelve proposals made by the Commission, including the recognition of professional qualifications.

We can clearly see that it is by increasing professional mobility that we can hope to unlock the growth potential contained in the internal market, our internal market of five hundred million inhabitants and five hundred million consumers.

Professional mobility must therefore enable, if we strengthen it, modernize it, and improve it, not only to ensure the free movement of our compatriots within this market, but also, we hope, to acquire additional margins of growth.
That is why we particularly want to emphasize a practical recommendation: we in the EPP have especially supported the implementation of a voluntary professional reform.
Madam President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Kaczmarek, for his excellent work.

Certainly, the crisis is economic and financial, but above all, for our fellow citizens, it is a social crisis.
Reducing the number of people in precarious situations by twenty million by the year 2020 requires strong measures involving different levels of public authority.

We need more than ever to fulfill the commitments made by the European Union in 2010 during the European Year for Combating Poverty and Social Exclusion and the creation of the European Platform against Poverty and Social Exclusion to have a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must perpetuate and optimize European funds, particularly the aid program for the most deprived, which is currently maintained, improve social protection, and support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, the elderly, and dependent persons.
Poverty is a scourge to be fought at a horizontal level and it is now time to act to enable the most deprived to escape their precarious situation.

We must, as political leaders at the European, national and local levels, take the necessary measures to ensure that they have access to housing, healthcare, justice, education and a first job with a minimum income that can be indexed according to the poverty threshold of each Member State, without discrimination.
Investing in the promotion of innovation and social experimentation and in the reduction of poverty will enable us to implement a strategy of sustainable, intelligent and inclusive growth.
The Europe we want and need today is a Europe of solidarity.

As the draftsperson of the opinion of the Committee on Development, I am pleased that the Committee on Fisheries has taken up the elements contained in our opinion, because it is crucial that the development dimension
be taken into account in measures to combat illegal fishing at global level, in the name of policy coherence and close links with development policy.
Indeed, the fight against illegal fishing requires comprehensive solutions and the involvement of all states, including developing ones.
However, it is necessary that the technical and financial capacities of the states are also taken into account in the actions to be undertaken.
Indeed, one cannot impose the same constraints without accompanying measures on developed or developing countries.
Small island states, for example, have very limited capacities.
They must therefore be supported in their efforts to combat illegal fishing.
This is why the Union will need to increase the financial envelope for the fisheries sector when it concludes agreements in this area in developing countries.

Furthermore, it is crucial that measures to combat illegal fishing are implemented, as this practice undermines the development of countries by reducing the financial resources that these countries could derive from the fishing industry.
Or, these resources are necessary for developing countries to implement social, economic, and education policies.

Finally, it is important that the European Union promotes, when implementing these measures to combat illegal fishing in developing countries, the involvement of civil society and businesses alongside the beneficiary states.
A holistic approach is necessary to stem the tide of this scourge that is illegal fishing. Thank you.
Mr President, I would like to say that it is largely thanks to these outermost regions that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power.

We believe it is important to ensure this dual movement of financial stability, budgetary discipline, and solidarity.
A final word on democracy.

Rather than thinking about resorting to a jurisdictional mechanism to impose sanctions in the case of budgetary excesses, I would suggest considering mechanisms of control and sanction exercised by democratic institutions.

States must send a strong signal.

This report is a warning signal to the states, but the European Commission must also play its role and verify the proper implementation of the waste directives.
This dossier must be made visible, but also credible.
If no one plays the game, we will continue to waste time and money on verification and counter-verification procedures that may last for years.
Let us listen to the message of the petitioners and stop this waste as quickly as possible.

Commissioner, the personal data protection standards of third countries still differ considerably from European standards.
However, it is our duty to ensure that our minimum European standards of protection, which we rely on, are respected and guaranteed to European citizens.
It is fundamental that personal data are processed fairly and collected for specified and legitimate purposes.
European citizens must be guaranteed the right to access and rectify personal data concerning them, as well as the right to file a legal complaint in the event of a violation of their rights.
Action must be taken to allow European and international standards to coexist and to resolve a potential legal conflict that could harm European citizens.
European legislation alone is not enough.
It must articulate and coexist intelligently with international standards, because we cannot shirk our duties and commitments to European citizens.
This situation echoes other debates within this chamber.
It reminds us of the relevance of projects such as the establishment of a European programme for monitoring the financing of terrorism.
Such a system would provide us with a tool that has proven effective in the United States, while fully respecting domestic law and, consequently, the protection of European citizens' personal data.
The European institutions must continue their commitment in this regard and fully assume their protection standards. Thank you.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to start by dispelling the unfounded allegations that between 500,000 and 1 million fake biometric passports are in circulation in France.
France takes the risk of identity document fraud very seriously
It does not take such offences lightly.
At the initiative of its government, identity theft is an offense punishable by one year in prison and a fine of fifteen euros.
The conditions for issuing identity documents have been simplified, allowing prefectures to free up additional resources to combat this fraud.
Thus, a fraud liaison officer is appointed in each prefecture.
In addition, the security measures for issuing identity documents have been strengthened.
For example, civil status data provided can be verified between administrative departments as much as possible by dematerialized means in order to limit the risks of falsification.
Some birth certificates are also issued on secure paper.
The same strictness applies to proof of address documents.
The Ministry of the Interior has embarked on a path towards increased security of proof of address with the insertion of a barcode.

The standard processing of a title application includes authorized consultation of relevant files, comparison of all documents submitted in previous title applications, and possible authentication of supporting documents.

The security of the issuance of documents is further guaranteed by the applicant's dual appearance: once at the time of the application submission and again when collecting the document, as well as the collection of two fingerprints.
And without mentioning the enhanced checks for renewing lost and stolen titles for comparative purposes with the data kept by the prefectures, I will conclude.
Furthermore, France informs international cooperation bodies, particularly Interpol, about passports issued, lost, or stolen so that they are not used for fraudulent purposes.
My dear colleagues, France, like the rest of the European Union, is committed to
Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, it is a fact that our fellow citizens increasingly wish to find and consume locally produced and seasonal food, particularly for health and quality reasons.
We must find ways to enable farmers to respond effectively and quickly to this growing demand.

We must support the establishment of local infrastructures for producers, such as maintaining nearby slaughterhouses, which, while ensuring rigorous health control, enable the development of local short supply chains and strengthen direct sales.
Support for local agriculture and direct sales should help producers to market their products and make them known to consumers.
Strengthening these direct relationships will enable peasants to retain a larger share of the added value created on their farms.

Direct sales on the farm should be encouraged and facilitated, and collective actions by farmers who wish to open collective sales points should be supported, allowing a wider range of products to be offered to local consumers.

The European Commission must facilitate the emergence, sustainability, and development of direct-to-consumer delivery sales systems, such as AMAPs in France, which enable nearly three farmers to supply sixty families.

Finally, Member States must be able to add other criteria, particularly concerning the size of the farm, the volume of production or the traditional nature of the product, in order to define local agriculture. Thank you.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that this amending budget concerning the funding of ITER, which was voted on by a large majority in the Committee on Budgets on 29 March,
By financing this additional cost, we avoid abandoning a strategic fundamental research project in which the European Union plays a leading role, and we honor our international commitments.

From 2015 to 2017, the building construction and machine assembly phase could employ up to four people on this site.
In conclusion, Mr. President, ITER is a source of pride for Europe and a symbol of our excellence.
Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur, thank you for the work we have done together.
The European Union needs a manifesto, a common political vision on the major challenges related to the environment, for the horizon of the year 2020 and beyond.
This is the whole point of launching a seventh environmental action programme, by creating synergy between existing financial frameworks and mobilising new funding resources.
This program must ensure consistency and coordination between the European Union's environmental strategies and sectoral policies, whether in agriculture,
fishing, research and innovation, health, transport, regional development, land use planning and urban policies, of course.
Despite the economic crisis that is battering the European Union, we must not succumb to a short-term vision and abandon all ambition in the environmental and climate field.
Inaction would be fatal.
The stakes are too high, especially when it comes to the effective use of our resources and the enhancement of natural capital.
We must therefore resolutely invest in sustainable economy and eco-innovation, which are sources of growth, competitiveness and employment.
It is our responsibility to promote eco-design, recycling, and the environmental labeling of products in order to avoid waste and poor consumption choices.
We cannot overlook this environmental education that is necessary for European citizens.
The environmental action programme is a political programming instrument, but it is also a communication tool.
It must provide the necessary readability and predictability to national and local governments, citizens, as well as entrepreneurs and investors regarding the European Union's environmental choices.
European regulation must not become a punishment or a straitjacket.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of the profound changes that our world is undergoing today, the EU must reform its generalised system of preferences.
Like any compromise, this one does not break the rule.
While it is satisfactory from a strictly commercial point of view, it is far from perfect, because we must bear in mind that this regulation is aimed at developing countries.
By developing its new paradigm of differentiation, the Commission says it wants to refocus its efforts on the poorest countries.
This does not seem entirely sustainable at first glance.
To achieve this, the Commission has nevertheless developed a strictly accounting approach based solely on the criterion of GDP per capita.
The limitations of this approach are clear.
What about the many middle-income developing countries with undiversified economies that are vulnerable to climate risks?
The compromise reached with the Council does not address this issue, which is why I am calling on my fellow Members to vote in favour of the three amendments that will be tabled on this text.
Commissioner, the problem of the availability of public consultations in the various languages of the European Union is unfortunately not new.
In my opinion, this is a crucial issue, for which I have already not only asked several written questions to the European Commission since 2008, but I have also personally written to Mr Barroso.

Indeed, the Commission must comply with the principle of equal access to information for all European citizens, as the Court of First Instance of the European Communities recalled in its judgment of November 20, 2008.
I was not at all satisfied with the European Commission's response, according to which public consultations do not claim to provide a completely representative picture of all opinions.
According to this response, the Commission takes into account the fact that certain positions and views may be overrepresented to the detriment of others.
That's not an answer.
I am wondering about the criteria that would allow us to measure an overrepresentation of the European population.
If written consultations are not overrepresented because of the sole availability in English, for example, they miss their goal of consulting European citizens.
Thus, the result gives a misleading indication and should therefore not be used by the European Commission.
If we want to maintain written consultations as a fundamental tool for the European Commission's legislative proposals, we must ensure a democratic, transparent, and fair process for all citizens.
Thus, if the European Commission opts for written consultations, it must take responsibility and ensure the necessary resources for multilingualism and the translation of questionnaires.
In conclusion, I would like to add that multilingualism is not the only obstacle

The analysis should also take into account the excessively short deadlines for submitting contributions, as well as the limited resources deployed by the Commission to communicate about these consultations, which are unfortunately mostly accessible to insiders. Thank you.
The proposed regulation aims to give the European Commission increased powers to control national budgets and economic policies.
The rules will be stricter, and defaulting states will be imposed by the technocrats in Brussels with budget cuts and structural reforms in order to restore their financial balance.
This enhanced monitoring is called guardianship.
States will be punished, fined, spanked, so to speak, financial sanctions will be strengthened and more automatic.
Even if some amendments aim to prevent budget austerity alone by means of growth measures, your proposals are only there to sweeten the pill.
Growth, as you know as well as I do, cannot be decreed.
Without consulting the people and with the complicity of Brussels, we are definitively losing our budgetary sovereignty, our freedom to choose our policies.

And when, little by little, according to the technique of the Chinese thief, the bureaucratic, technocratic, and totalitarian European state has finally been established, we will have lost our freedom as a people altogether.
Mr President, without underestimating the importance of the economic choices we have to face up to, allow me to insist on a point of a more political nature in the context of this debate.
In recent weeks, we have once again seen evidence of the double-speak of certain major European leaders, or those who believe themselves to be such.
While everyone continues to advocate for a coordination of economic, budgetary, and fiscal policies that is finally worthy of the name, and while this requirement even appears to be a condition
an essential condition for the survival of the eurozone, and yet, once settled in his own country, Mr. Croix Malin denounces the balanced recommendations coming from
the Commission to free itself from certain commitments or, in the worst case scenario, to turn public opinion against these Brussels bureaucrats, as they call themselves.
This irresponsible attitude would be laughable if we were not in such a tragic situation.
I'll tell you straight, our debates on stability, the necessary improvement of public finances, or the efforts to be made in terms of growth are indeed doomed to
failure if the past mistakes in terms of debt and public deficit do not come to an end and if the governments of the Member States continue their misadventure.
We are playing with fire right now.
European discipline must apply to everyone, without exception, even to the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.
This requires a minimum of courage and our public opinion is ready for it, much more so than some of their leaders would like to believe.
And one last word to Mrs. Goulard, otherwise I must show her the blue card, I would say in conclusion to Mrs. Goulard, in redemption there is redemption.

Mr President, I would first like to commend the determination of the European Commission, and particularly yours, Commissioner, for tirelessly placing the relaunch and deepening of the internal market at the top of the European agenda.

As you reminded us, Commissioner, it has been more than two years now that both the Commission and the European Parliament have been working to identify the missing links in the internal market, to identify the issues and sectors that require more internal market, more internal market for more growth, more competitiveness, more jobs.

The European Council, for its part, also ended up, albeit more belatedly, by signaling the importance it attached to the rapid and effective implementation of the twelve priority proposals for the internal market, the twelve levers for growth.
Rather than constantly trying to invent new growth instruments, we would be better off working with the toolkit we already have.

We therefore seize the opportunity of the resolution that will be put to a vote by our Assembly tomorrow to send a strong political message to the Member States about the need for greater speed and efficiency in transposing directives that are already in place.
adopted more mobilization and commitment in the newly opened projects, I will mention just one: the strengthening of worker mobility, more ease of movement, more fluidity of movement.
Commissioner, we will be eagerly awaiting the second stage of the act for the single market that you will present after the summer.
We will demonstrate both political will and the ability to put pressure on the member states.
We experienced the mediator scandal some time ago.
We now have the breast implant scandal, which unfortunately highlights, as you said, Commissioner, the shortcomings in European health safety.
This breast implant scandal, these fourteen years of fraud from 1996 to 2010, went unpunished,
There are five hundred prostheses used worldwide, these eight implant recalls, and forty-eight confirmed cases of cancer.
Finally, three complaints have been filed. These figures are frightening, shocking.

How, despite the warnings from the American FDA, Commissioner, and the numerous complaints and convictions for implant rupture filed in Great Britain and France in particular, how have the national and European agencies been able to overlook such a scam?
This tragedy immediately prompted us to consider improving the European system for monitoring medical devices, as you explained to us just now.
We must, Commissioner, build a new system today that can prevent scandal, but it is a new system that needs to be built.
This new legislation is scheduled for the autumn, as you mentioned.
As a co-author of this resolution, I am obviously satisfied with it.
But, Commissioner, you seem to want to take into account a large part of our concerns as dictated by this resolution.
So why make an unacceptable exception for many of the parliamentarians present here?
Why not want the creation of a marketing authorization for the highest-risk class three medical devices
Commissioner Dali, can you explain your position to me?
Mr. President, we are currently experiencing a situation with an increase in production of more than 2.5%. At the same time, manufacturers are lowering prices.
In Italy, Germany, England and throughout Europe, prices are falling.
This means very clearly that prices are linked to the volume of production, and we need to organize the volumes of production and prices at the same time.
At the same time, today, producers are suffering from an increase of more than forty-four percent in the price of vegetable proteins and thirty percent in the price of cereals.
Parliament has already voted on the need to ensure that the added value is shared between producers and that farmers are not the victims of companies and large-scale distribution.

I am therefore asking the Commission today, but also the Council, to reconsider the undermining of control over production, but at the same time, I am saying very clearly that the Member States must clean up their own back yards, because there are countries that have complied with the quota rules and others that have not.
And that is also why these quotas have been called into question.
So there is a dual responsibility, that of the Commission and that of the Member States.
Commissioner, dear colleagues, a single European rail area: what a fine example of European integration policy.
This is a fine policy where European construction is at the heart of the daily concerns of Europeans.

Too often criticized, because it was at a standstill, Europe, finally, through this directive, is showing the way for a major sustainable transport policy and is opening up the field for a major rail investment policy for employment.

I welcome the main measures taken in the organisation of the rail network: the establishment of national regulators in each Member State, the creation of a five-year multiannual investment contract, thereby stipulating the funding commitments of the

railway infrastructure, but I am also pleased about the introduction of transparency in financial flows between managers and operators within integrated companies. The reminder about non-discriminatory access to certain

services. Finally, I welcome the confirmation by European parliamentarians of certain guarantees, particularly on the social front, for example, the absence of a reference to minimum service, as well as full unbundling between the manager and the operator.

But allow me to mention a requirement that is no longer being considered, particularly by the European Commission: the liberalization of the railway sector as the only strategic goal for the development of a single railway area, and the decision to adopt a European integrated investment strategy that is favorable to employment in Europe.
So, to conclude, I would like to ask you a question, Commissioner Callas.
This is three days after the European Council of June 28 and 29, after the validation of a growth pact of 120 billion euros to relaunch the European economy.
notably through investment in infrastructure. Could you tell us, Commissioner, how much funding the European rail sector is likely to receive under this growth pact?
Madam President, we will have a debate on ACTA tomorrow, but I would like to address an issue this evening, which is certainly peripheral, but extremely important in this context.
These were the remarks made by Commissioner Gutt before the Committee on International Trade on Wednesday, June 20.

I quote him. If you decide on a negative vote before the European Court rules, let me tell you that the Commission will nevertheless continue to pursue the current procedure before the Court of Justice.
we are committed to it.
A negative vote will not halt the proceedings before the Court of Justice.

This is not only an ignorance of the treaties, but above all, and this is what I want to denounce, it shows an unacceptable contempt for the European Parliament, for democracy in general, and for the citizens we represent.
At a time when European citizens, as a whole,
Thank you, Mr. President. A lot has been said at this point.
Mr Commissioner, for my part, I would like to thank you most sincerely.
Thanks to your persistence, to your procedural tricks, you are allowing us to prove the importance of the European Parliament as a co-legislator.
Thank you, Commissioner, for having pushed hundreds of thousands of citizens to take to the streets and two million eight hundred thousand to sign petitions.
They discovered that democracy is at stake here, that we, the European elected officials, are the representatives of the people, their representatives.
Once again, thank you to the millions of internet users who followed the debates and votes in committee and who are still following us today.
I salute them. It's a breath of fresh air in our institutions, which are all too often perceived as technocratic.
Commissioner, but in a democracy, there is also another principle.
This is the fundamental principle, that of responsibility.
Tomorrow, we will take responsibility, and I would like, tomorrow, to thank you for taking responsibility for your failure, the failure of your working method.
I am speaking on behalf of Maurice Ponga, draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development on Mr Gallagher's report.
It seemed important to me to point out that when the European Union wishes to sanction a country that practices unsustainable fishing, it must take into account its level of development.

In fact, in the name of the principle of policy coherence with development objectives, it is crucial, in my opinion, that measures adopted in the field of fisheries do not undermine the development plans and strategies implemented by the European Union in these countries.
Mr. Gallagher's draft report takes up this important idea for our Development Committee by stipulating that measures must not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

I therefore call on the European Commission, when adopting such measures, to respect this principle of policy coherence with development objectives and to ensure that the level of development and vulnerability of countries are duly taken into account. Thank you.
This third reform of the common fisheries policy must not once again be carried out against the interests of fishermen.

No, not all fishermen are these plunderers of the sea, solely responsible for the poor health of fish stocks, as environmental organizations and the European Commission claim by lumping all categories of fishing together.

It goes without saying that it is necessary to preserve fish stocks, but we must also allow our fishermen to make a living from their activity and preserve the economic fabric, dynamism, and cultural identity of our coastal regions.
Or, the main measures of the European executive once again aim to reduce the number of fishermen in order to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield.
I would like to remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than fifty since 1980.

The Commission proposes, in particular, the introduction of individual transferable quotas, which are a sign of industrialization and concentration in the sector, or the total ban on discards, which professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project is probably suitable for the industrial fleet, but as it stands, it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and artisanal fishing.

Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the EPP rapporteur, our colleague Karins, on this difficult report, given the sensitive nature of bilateral negotiations in the field of energy between European countries and third countries.
The agreement reached in trilogue will allow for the rapid implementation of the Commission's draft decision, and for pragmatic reasons, one can only welcome this.
Europe's energy transition is certainly not progressing quickly enough, but it is progressing.
As a major energy importer, the European Union is structurally dependent on certain supplier countries.

In order to have a more European reflection on our energy strategy, it had become necessary to disseminate information on energy agreements more widely to the European Commission, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity.
The establishment of an information mechanism on intergovernmental agreements will therefore improve transparency in the energy market and thus make it possible to anticipate energy supply problems.
I am pleased that this decision does not create any obligation regarding agreements between commercial companies.
In times of crisis and given the stakes in terms of competition and competitiveness, we had to protect the interests of our companies and the rules protecting private contracts.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to thank our two rapporteurs for the work they have done on this issue.

It was necessary because we were starting from a very long way off with the Commission's basic proposal: no specific mention of the outermost regions directly affected by competition from Latin American countries, no automatic triggering.

under the stabilisation mechanism, there is no possibility for our Assembly to request the initiation of a safeguard investigation, and social and environmental standards are not taken into account as potentially constituting an unfair competitive advantage.
That is why it is extremely important that tomorrow's vote validates the progress made on these points in the Committee on International Trade.
Nevertheless, this is not enough because we know that the trigger thresholds for these two regulations are so high that they make these mechanisms practically inapplicable.
Furthermore, the Commission must provide an additional financial envelope to support the competitiveness of Community banana production.
Keep in mind that many jobs are at stake in these European regions that already have record unemployment rates.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to start by thanking Charles Goerens for his excellent report.
We all know here that the European Union provides more than half of the world's total official development assistance, and yet, as the MDG deadline approaches in 2015, even though some goals seem
Having achieved these results, we must ask ourselves how we can improve our aid, how we can make it more consistent with our trade policy, our agricultural policy, and our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must be based on specific, measurable commitments with a short- and medium-term timeline.

The economic crisis, climate change, the power of emerging countries, and land grabbing force us to define new priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources, and access to healthcare.

Certainly, there is a European consensus, but we must rethink European and international institutional systems in environmental and social matters, drawing inspiration from organizations that function well in terms of decision-making, such as the WTO, for example.
Finally and most importantly, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third countries is not just about charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
One need only look at the markets opening up for Europeans in emerging countries like China, Brazil, and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to better take into account the geostrategic evolution of recent years, as the emerging countries of today were still developing countries just a short time ago.
As major economic powers, these countries must now also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must be the promoter of responsible development aid at European and international levels.

The year 2015 will be more than just a deadline; it will be a unique opportunity to rethink development aid, not as mere financial assistance, but as support for responsible development projects, both socially and environmentally.

I therefore join here with my colleagues from the other groups and those from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions in calling for 2015 to be designated the European Year of Development and, above all, of responsible development.
Mr President, the agenda for change proposed by the Commission raises, in my opinion, many questions, the main one being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission wishes that, starting in 2014, the selection of countries in which the European Union will invest its development aid be based on the mechanical application of the simple criterion of per capita wealth.
Or, as Mrs Ashton pointed out, these issues are not just accounting matters, but deserve a genuine political debate on the definition of our priorities in terms of international cooperation.
Moreover, in my opinion, this differentiated approach is not in line with the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance should be encouraged in their transition towards more sustainable growth. These countries should not be unduly penalized for having succeeded in ensuring growth through discipline, good governance, and prudent economic policies.
Madam President, Commissioner, let us salute the initiative taken by Jacques Delors twenty years ago, at the very moment when the Berlin Wall was falling.

Despite this, despite all the progress we have seen since the beginning of our debate, it is forced to be noted that the Single Act is today synonymous with injustice, inequality, and economic liberalism.
I would therefore like to hear from you, Mr Barnier, Commissioner, to tell us how we are going to build a fairer Europe together, a facilitating Europe, a protective Europe.

There are a number of avenues, and I would like to hear your thoughts on these avenues that are at the heart of the economic and social crisis as we unfortunately know it: tax harmonization, public services,
protector of the minimum wage in Europe, establishment of enhanced cooperation, job creation, facilitating cross-border cooperation, and developing a fair trade policy.
These are the challenges, I believe, that lie ahead of us twenty years later.
I am counting on you, Commissioner, to work together to advance this fine policy of European construction.

Mr President, as a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have taken a close interest in my colleague Regina Bastos's report on the twenty main concerns of citizens and businesses.
and we discussed this report in connection with our debate on the twentieth anniversary of the internal market.
It has already been twenty years since the free movement of goods, people, services, and capital was supposed to be fully implemented within our living space, exchange space, and internal market.

I was particularly interested in the fact that the existence of professional qualifications is at the forefront of the concerns expressed by our European fellow citizens, and that we really need to be particularly proactive and particularly effective.

This is what our fellow citizens expect in order to truly be able to implement, in the very near future, procedures for recognizing their diplomas, skills, and professional qualifications that are truly faster, simpler, more efficient, and less costly.
It is a real challenge.
As the shadow rapporteur for the EPP group on this subject of modernising these procedures, I am actively working with other members of the IMCO committee to address this major challenge of mobility.
More mobility, for more Europe, that is what our fellow citizens are asking for. Thank you.
Mr President, this year the Committee on Petitions acquired the right to be automatically associated with the hearing of European citizens' initiatives.
For me, this is the most significant signal of the year 2011 for this Commission.
Citizens already had a commission to turn to in case of violation of their rights, but this is now also the case when they have proposals to improve European legislation.
I hope that the Committee on Petitions can thus be increasingly seen as the preferred interlocutor for citizens in the European Parliament.
This issue of consideration is also reflected in the results of the Committee on Petitions' positions.
All too often, we are approached by citizens who are facing legal entanglements on which we would like to take a stand. But while the problems are European, then
while solutions should be European, we remain powerless because subsidiarity is still not compatible with European solutions due to a lack of national will.
I will take the difficult example of transnational divorces. The problems are both national and European when custody or visitation rights cross national borders, in this case those of Germany.
Despite the glaring difficulties faced by many parents of children born of binational unions, we in Parliament remain powerless to act.

My proposal for all European citizens to have the right to a national ombudsman, especially from Germany, which sends a large number of petitions following the model of the Defender of Rights in France, has not been implemented.
However, in the case of transnational divorces, this remains a solution that reconciles the European problem with the national solution.
In many cases, European law seems powerless to meet citizens' expectations.
The European Year of Citizenship 2013 must address citizens' grievances, listening is essential, but we need the means to act in order to be effective.
